title: HUMANS IN SHACKLES
description: ‚ÄúRaised as a white person‚Äù in southern Brazil, Howard University professor Araujo is determined to include in her account both Latin America and those regions from which enslaved Africans were kidnapped. Synthesizing primary sources and other historians‚Äô findings, she works her way from West Africa and West Central Africa, through the Middle Passage, to the Americas, then back again. As she contrasts the experiences of bondspeople across time and space, she takes care to explore the lives of enslaved women and to highlight enslaved people‚Äôs persistent efforts at resistance. Encouraging readers to understand suicide, infanticide, and celebration as expressions of resistance, Araujo argues that ‚Äúbondspeople were protagonists of their own emancipation.‚Äù Araujo‚Äôs ¬†writing can sometimes be dry, but this does not diminish the importance of her work. The facts alone are staggering; among them: ‚ÄúMore than 4.8 million enslaved [people] landed on Brazilian shores‚Ä¶nearly ten times more than [in] the United States.‚Äù Seeing Nat Turner‚Äôs Rebellion of 1831 alongside Tacky‚Äôs Revolt in Jamaica in 1760 and the Mal√™ Revolt in Brazil in 1835 helps readers understand the scope of enslaved people‚Äôs armed resistance. Also astonishing is the range of sources from which Araujo and her colleagues glean information: In addition to slave narratives and oral tradition, she cites Inquisition records, enslaved people‚Äôs wills, and a particularly revealing 1684 Portuguese law regulating conditions on slave ships, among a wealth of other documents.

title: THE TIME KEEPER
description: The orphaned Malcolm lives in Mrs. McCardle‚Äôs Home for Children and is apprenticed to Jack Alexander, a clockmaker and inventor. Malcolm‚Äôs good friends with Jack‚Äôs son, Peter, and is a regular visitor to the Alexander home, where Peter‚Äôs aunt also lives. The novel unfolds around two intertwining and mysterious misfortunes that strike the family: a strange illness that Peter succumbs to, followed by Jack‚Äôs murder. Mahoney explores the world of Edinburgh‚Äôs first generation of female physicians through the character of Dr. Fiona MacIsaac, who plays a prominent role in Peter‚Äôs care and is present when Malcolm discovers Jack‚Äôs body in a locked church tower. When Malcolm takes up Jack‚Äôs interrupted quest to help Peter, Dr. MacIsaac provides a crucial piece of the puzzle‚Äîan item that may lead to a healing serum. Malcolm‚Äôs sleuthing leads him all over the city and offers insights into the fascinating and intricate worlds of early-20th-century medicine and clockmaking. This mystery, which features a white-presenting cast, will appeal to readers who enjoy historical settings, intriguing puzzles, and some element of danger. The author brings to life the richly evoked Edinburgh through descriptive writing as well as its residents‚Äô speech patterns.
